=== The military's role ===
=== The military's role ===
â
{{empty section}}
+
{{main|Military of Egypt}}
  +   +
The [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] enjoy a better reputation with the public than the police do, the former perceived as a professional body protecting the country, the latter accused of systemic corruption and illegitimate violence. All four [[Egyptian president]]s since the 1950s have come from the military into power. Key Egyptian military personnel include the defense minister [[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]] and General [[Sami Hafez Enan]], chief of staff of the armed forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110213/D9LC1NLO0.html |title=Key members of Egypt Armed Forces Supreme Council |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Ian Black (journalist)|Black, Ian]]|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-military-hosni-mubarak|title=All Eyes on Egypt's Military as Hosni Mubarak Fortifies Position |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Egyptian military totals around 468,500 well-armed active personnel, plus a reserve of 479,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/30/uk-egypt-protests-military-idUKTRE70T29420110130|title=Factbox â Egypt's Powerful Military|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>

===Foreign relations===
  +
{{main|Foreign relations of Egypt}}
  +
Foreign governments in the West including the US have regarded Mubarak as an important ally and [[Foreign relations of Egypt#Israeli-Palestinian conflict|supporter]] in the [[Israeli-Palestinian conflict|Israeli-Palestinian]] peace negotiations.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> After wars with [[Israel]] in 1967 and '73, Egypt signed a [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] in 1979, provoking controversy in the [[Arab world]]. As provisioned in the 1978 [[Camp David Accords]], which led to the peace treaty, both Israel and Egypt receive billions of dollars in aid annually from the United States, with Egypt receiving over US$1.3 billion of military aid each year in addition to economic and development assistance.<ref>{{cite web| title = Background Note: Egypt| publisher=[[United States Department of State]]| date =10 November 2010| url = http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm| accessdate = 28 January 2011}}</ref> Many Egyptian youth feel ignored by Mubarak on the grounds that he is not looking out for their best interests and that he rather serves the interests of the [[West]].{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=this is based on opinion essay (by juan cole). needs clear wording and proper disclosure that it is cole speaking and not Wikipedia with OR.}}<ref name="cole">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/30/opinion/main20030008.shtml|title=Why Egypt's Class Conflict Is Boiling Over â Juan Cole: How Decades of Economic Stumbles Set the Stage for Egypt's Current Political Turmoil|author=Cole, Juan ([[essay]])|date=30 January 2011|work=[[CBS News]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> The cooperation of the Egyptian regime in enforcing the [[blockade of the Gaza Strip]] was also deeply unpopular amongst the general Egyptian public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/jan/25/egypt.israelandthepalestinians1 |title=Mubarak under pressure | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
